name: House Wilfson
notes: Hereditary Castellans & Masters of the Silver Mines.

name: House Wilfrey of Riverhead
notes: One of the four great Wilfrey seats. Commands strategic river position and supplies half the food for the Wilfrey domain. Known for using food as political leverage.

name: House Wilfriver
notes: Cadet branch of moderate political standing but ill repute. Control river barge trade as legitimate front. Widely suspected of smuggling contraband up and down the river using retainers and unsavoury types. Never caught.

name: House Salter of the Scorch
notes: Lords of the Scorch (the Dust Bowl) - a hardscrabble inland region poor in water and good soil but rich in salt deposits. The marriage alliance with Riverhead creates economic interdependence: water and food for salt.

name: House Bridger of Longford
notes: Control a major ford and crossing point downstream from Riverhead. Marriage secures river trade routes and toll income. A practical, mercantile house.

name: House Ironfell of the Marchlands
notes: Border house known for martial prowess, guarding against external threats. Rocky, defensible lands but food-poor, making Riverhead's agricultural surplus valuable. Lord Faraday's sister married here, cementing a military alliance.

name: House Millward
notes: Minor lords sworn to Riverhead. Millers and grain merchants along the river. Lady Elspeth, wife of Lord Faraday, comes from this house.

name: House Reedham
notes: Minor lords sworn to Riverhead. Lords of the marshlands - fishermen and fowlers. Rennick Wilfrey (son of Kellam) married a daughter of this house.

name: House Tillbrook
notes: Minor lords sworn to Riverhead. Farmers holding rich fields upstream from the castle. Lord Goram Wilfriver's wife Hella comes from this house.

name: House Wilfern
notes: House Wilfern holds a minor castle on the Western foothills of night mountain

name: House Wilson
notes:
House Wilson is a broken branch of House Wilfrey, granted leave by the crown in 1785 to break from Wilfrey Drith authority,
   following the dramas of the 57th family council. The Founding Lord was granted the lands and estate of an extinct family  
  that had come back to crown control.

name: House Thornbury
notes: Drith-level landed family from the eastern reaches, known for horse breeding. Outside the Wilfrey web but of respectable standing.
